field_edited_text.value:
BE'R'R'E'R'EER'E'E'EER
vill. HARBOR ROUTE AND RELATED

PROPOSALS

After studying the Northern Route to determine if improvements
could be made in its alignment, attention was next directed to the location
of substantially different routes.

It will be recalled that Chapter VI of this report sets forth three
basic requirements which should be met by any route for an East-West
Expressway. These requirements were: First, it should be approvable for
inclusion in the National Interstate Highway System; second, interchange
with the Jones Falls Expressway must be feasible; and third, good service
must be provided to the central business district.

Only one new route was discovered which met all of these require-
ments satisfactorily. This route is referred to in this report as the Harbor
Route. The complete route is shown on Sheet 7. The detailed alignment
is set forth on Sheets 8 through 12 and 23 through 28.

From the western City line to Myrtle Avenue the Harbor Route is
identical to the Northern Route. For the following reasons it was decided
to make no change in this section:

1. The crossing of the western City boundary is in effect fixed if the
East-West Expressway is to be eligible for inclusion as part of the
Interstate Highway System.

2. From the western City boundary to Hilton Street the route passes
through Leakin Park and Gwynns Falls Park. While it would
normally be undesirable to use park land for highway purposes,
the City owns a very large amount of park land in this general
area and those portions needed for the Expressway would, for the
most part, be located in the high isolated rugged areas south of
Dead Run. In effect, the Expressway path jumps from hill to
hill and approximately one-third of the total length within the
park would be elevated. There would be no interference between
the Expressway and any developed sections of the park, nor would

38

there be any conflict with present foot or vehicle circulation
within the park. Most present entrance roads into the City are
unsightly; this one would have great beauty. Total park land
required would be about 85 acres, of which about 35 would be
needed for the Hilton Street interchange. This reduction in park
acreage can be replaced in whole or in part by the purchase of
additional vacant land adjacent to the park. Already two parcels
at the western end of Leakin Park have been acquired to prevent
development in the path of the Expressway. When the Express-
way requirements have been met there will remain about 25 acres
in these two parcels which can easily be added to the Park. The
only alternative to the use of park land at this point would be
to run the Expressway through the high-grade residential areas
to the north or to the south.

. The stretch running between Mulberry and Franklin Streets from

the Pennsylvania Railroad on the west to Myrtle Avenue on the
east (a little less than a mile and one-half) has long been ear-
marked for clearance for highway purposes and much planning
during the past ten years has been based on the understanding
that an expressway would be located here. Two public housing
projects located just to the east of Fremont Avenue have been
developed with this Expressway in mind, and the plan for the
Harlem Park Urban Renewal Area has been predicated on this
assumption. The heavy streams of traffic which now flow on
Mulberry and Franklin Streets have made the area between these
two streets highly undesirable for residential purposes and many,
if not most, of the structures between these two streets are so
dilapidated that they should be torn down. With or without the
Expressway, Franklin and Mulberry Streets will continue to be
